report_title: Industry Report on Assisted Living Facilities
executive_summary: The aging demographics of the United States have driven the growth of the Assisted Living Facilities industry. The number of adults aged 65 and older has been increasing consistently for the past two decades. Since the elderly are prone to injury and illness, many of them require assistance with their daily activities. The growing share of senior adults has propelled the need for services offered by assisted living facilities. As a result, the industry has struggled through the COVID-19 pandemic, but industry revenue has risen. Revenue is expected to grow at a CAGR of 2.7% to $45.5 billion over the five years to 2024, including growth of 2.9% during the current year. However, the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic created a severe disruption to the industry. The virus is especially dangerous to adults aged 65 and older, so assisted living facilities were particularly vulnerable to deadly outbreaks.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Aging Population Has Produced a Surge in Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the baby boomer generation continues to enter retirement age, demand for senior care services has surged. This has especially been the case for assisted living facilities, which cater to seniors that are not yet in need of nursing care. The number of adults aged 65 and older has risen at a significantly faster rate than the overall population. Many needs of an aging population often can't be met at home, driving demand for assisted living facilities.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Created Significant Challenges for the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 significantly threatened industry operations. The virus is especially dangerous to adults aged 65 and older, so assisted living facilities were particularly vulnerable to deadly outbreaks at the height of the pandemic. With deaths occurring at significantly higher rates at facilities, many seniors opted to avoid to avoid assisted living facilities to reduce additional risk. The industry saw revenue contractions in 2020 and 2021 as a result, the first in more than a decade. Likewise, profit margins sank on account of reduced occupancy rates. With concerns about COVID-19 subsiding, the burgeoning elderly population will continue to propel the industry to growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Elderly Population Will Continue to Increase
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The number of adults aged 65 and older will continue to grow at a faster rate than the overall economy, reliably replenishing occupancy rates in assisted living facilities. Many adults over the age of 65 have been delaying retirement. People who have remained in the workforce until later in life have stronger savings accounts and pensions, better enabling them to afford the retirement lifestyle of their choosing. Assisted living facilities, which allow for more independent living lifestyles, are largely paid for by residents out-of-pocket.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Assisted Living Facilities Will See Consolidation
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will see rising consolidation following the COVID-19 pandemic. Facilities can expand services through consolidation, benefiting from shared operational expenses. Expanding economies of scale will be crucial to the industry as government reimbursement rates continue to decline. Fluctuating Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement rates and tougher pricing negotiations will put some pressure on facilities.

industry_definition: This industry provides a range of residential and personal care services for the elderly and other persons who are unable to fully care for themselves, or those that do not care to live independently.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Number of adults aged 65 and older

key_trends: The growing elderly population in the United States has generated strong demand for assisted living facilities. Occupancy rates at assisted living facilities have risen in line with the rising number of Americans over the age of 65.

Residents at assisted living facilities were particularly vulnerable to COVID-19. Facility residents and staff became some of the first individuals eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in December 2020.
Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements cover many services for patients in assisted living facilities. Federal funding and reimbursement rates can vary greatly from year to year and state to state.
There are strict federal, state and local regulations that assisted living facilities must follow. These regulations are in place to ensure safety for residents.
Resident primarily pay for assisted living facilities with out-of-pocket payments. However, payments from Medicare and Medicaid constitute an important secondary funding source.

Assisted living facilities give residents assistance with completing daily tasks while monitoring their health. These services range from housekeeping and meal preparation to assistance with bathing and dressing.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Out-of-pocket payments are generated through lifelong accumulation of assets, a home sale or with financial assistance from family members. Assisted living facilities require high household incomes, as the cost of industry services is steep.

A lot of payments are generated through Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements. Medicaid reimbursements are expected to constitute the majority of this percentage. Coverage of industry services through Medicaid changes widely between states, since the program is funded by both the federal and state governments.
Some residents supplement out-of-pocket cost for care with a form of private insurance. Private pay residents that enter facility can become eligible for Medicaid as they deplete their assets.

Seniors can use any worker's compensation they have. In some cases, property auto and casualty insurance can help cover part of a stay. People give contributions and grants to many nonprofits, which can be used to provide care to those who need it most.

products_and_services.product_description: Assisted living facilities are state-regulated properties that cater to seniors who need help with personal care and daily activities, yet also wish to retain some independence.
Facilities provide a range of living services, include assistance with simple domestic tasks.
These living services range from housekeeping and meal preparation to assistance with bathing and dressing.

tier_1_suppliers: Medical Supplies Wholesaling in the US
Drug, Cosmetic & Toiletry Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Medical Instrument & Supply Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Health & Medical Insurance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industry is highly fragmented, with many assisted living facilities serving localized communities. Still, some companies have consolidated with other facilities as the aging population ensures a consistent source of demand.

A certificate of need is a legal document required before proposed acquisitions, expansions or creations of assisted living facilities are permitted. CON regulations are issued by state healthcare agencies and are mandatory to construct a medical facility in 36 states.

Assisted living facilities depend on their relationships with hospitals. Hospitals have a choice of where to send discharged patients for extended care, making the reputation of a facility tantamount to success.

Patients may prefer to stay within the comfort of their own homes, as opposed to moving into an assisted living facility. These patients can opt for an at-home care provider who can act as a nurse, homemaker and companion to them.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of both establishments (around 30%) and population (around 25%).
The West region has the second-highest percentage of both establishments (around 20%) and population (around 20%).
The Mid-Atlantic region has a higher percentage of establishments (around 15%) than population (around 10%).
The percentage of establishments in the Great Lakes region is around 10% while the percentage of population is around 15%.
The New England region has around 5% of both establishments and population.
The Southwest region has around 10% of both establishments and population.
The Rocky Mountains region has around 5% of both establishments and population.
The Plains region has the lowest percentage of both establishments (around 5%) and population (around 5%).

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is highly fragmented, with many assisted living facilities serving localized communities. Still, some companies have consolidated with other facilities as the aging population ensures a consistent source of demand.

A certificate of need is a legal document required before proposed acquisitions, expansions or creations of assisted living facilities are permitted. CON regulations are issued by state healthcare agencies and are mandatory to construct a medical facility in 36 states.

Assisted living facilities depend on their relationships with hospitals. Hospitals have a choice of where to send discharged patients for extended care, making the reputation of a facility tantamount to success.

Patients may prefer to stay within the comfort of their own homes, as opposed to moving into an assisted living facility. These patients can opt for an at-home care provider who can act as a nurse, homemaker and companion to them.

basis_points.basis_title: Interpretation of the graph "Distribution of Establishments vs Population"
basis_points.basis_description: The graph shows the percentage distribution of establishments (likely businesses or companies) and population across different regions of the United States. The regions included are Great Lakes, Mid-Atlantic, New England, Plains, Rocky Mountains, Southeast, Southwest, and West. The data is presented in a stacked bar chart, with one bar representing the percentage of establishments and the other bar representing the percentage of population for each region.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The visual appears to be a bar chart showing the market share concentration in the assisted living facilities industry. The bar representing the market share concentration is labeled "LOW concentration", indicating a low level of market concentration with many players and no dominant firm holding a significant market share. This suggests a fragmented market with numerous small and medium-sized assisted living facility providers operating in localized markets.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Occupancy rates measure the degree to which assisted living facilities are using beds that are available for patients.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: When beds are in high demand, assisted living facilities can refuse government-reimbursed residents in favor of those with private insurers. In areas with low occupancy rates, assisted living facilities are forced to accept low-paying Medicaid and Medicare residents.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Pressure from spending cuts and lower reimbursement rates have caused employment to contract in recent years.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Employee-related expenses can vary depending on several factors, including the size of the portfolio of facilities, the type of facilities in the portfolio and the location of facilities.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower. However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The essential nature of services better insulates them from economic fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: Assisted living facilities fulfill a societal need that only grows as years go on, so industry activity is better insulated from economic conditions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Assisted living facilities are state-regulated properties that cater to seniors who need help with personal care and daily activities, yet also wish to retain some independence. Assisted living facilities aim to provide as much autonomy as the resident is capable of. Most facilities offer 24-hour supervision and a variety of support services.

Facilities provide a range of living services, include assistance with simple domestic tasks. These living services range from housekeeping and meal preparation to assistance with bathing and dressing.

FAQs.question: How does your company market its services to the wider community?
FAQs.answer: Assisted living facilities mainly operate on a local level. Word of mouth and community reputation is key for operators to draw residents to their establishments.

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need?
FAQs.answer: People typically visit assisted living facilities close to their families. Moreover, states with higher populations of seniors are more likely to attract assisted living facilities. The increasing share of people aged 65 and older in the population decreases vacancy rates as the size of this population requiring care grows from year to year. However, changes in government reimbursement policies can affect revenue, as reimbursement rates dictate the services assisted living facilities offer.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: Technology assisted living facilities can invest in digital record keeping software.

FAQs.question: Have your regulatory expenses been impacted by federal healthcare reform?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare reform has lowered Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement, pressuring profit margins for assisted living facilities.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Targeting patients with private insurance or the ability to pay out-of-pocket helps companies keep profit margins high.

FAQs.question: How have you increased your reputation? Have you had any issues maintaining a good reputation?
FAQs.answer: Clients are more likely to trust an assisted living facility if current residents would recommend it.

FAQs.question: What kind of facilities do you maintain? Do you have plans of updated facilities in the future?
FAQs.answer: Demand for assisted living facilities is largely based on the location and quality of the facility.

FAQs.question: What skills do you require for your workforce? Have you had difficulty having access to a skilled workforce?
FAQs.answer: As a labor-intensive industry, assisted living facilities need skilled employees that can provide high quality service.

FAQs.question: How did your company fare amid the pandemic's resulting economic climate? How have you performed with overall growth in disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income measures the amount of money the average person has left over after paying for necessities. When disposable income rises, people are better able to pay for industry services out-of-pocket.

FAQs.question: How has the current level of total health expenditure affected your company? How can you adapt as total health expenditure increases?
FAQs.answer: As an industry that provides healthcare services, the Assisted Living Facilities industry typically benefits from an increase in health expenditure.

FAQs.question: Do you anticipate an increase in demand for services as the population ages? Have you noticed a shift in your patient demographic?
FAQs.answer: When the elderly population increases, so does demand for assisted living facilities because this increases the market for senior care.
